docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration today approved the first substantially new contraceptive in 25 years, a set of small, soft tubes that are implanted under a woman's skin where they release a hormone that can prevent conception for five years. The method is essentially a new way of delivering the female hormone progestin, which along with estrogen is one of two components in current birth control pills. The implant can be put into place in a simple surgical procedure in a doctor's office. Fertility is restored by the next menstrual cycle after the implants are removed. 'The Dream Method' "In some ways it is the dream method that people who work on birth control have looked for for decades," said Dr. Daniel Callahan, director of the Hastings Center, a research institution in Briarcliffe Manor, N.Y., that studies issues of medical ethics. "It is long-acting and would make a woman infertile until she takes an active decision not to be."

headline.main: U.S. Approves Contraceptives Planted in Skin
